Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Story:
I glanced at the dashboard clock as I navigated the quiet afternoon streets, my passenger relaxed in the back seat, scrolling through his phone. My phone buzzed in the cup holder—right on time, as always. It was Sunday, the day I called my parents to check in, to hear about their week, to reassure them I was doing fine. I could already imagine my mother’s gentle voice, my father’s questions about my work. They counted on these calls, and so did I, in a way.

But I was on the job, and even though my passenger wasn’t in a rush, I knew the rules: no distractions, keep my eyes on the road, make sure every ride was safe and professional. The company expected it, and so did my passengers. My hand hovered over the phone, torn between the comfort of my parents’ voices and the responsibility of the steering wheel. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my attention, each unwilling to wait. My heart thudded as I wrestled with what to do next.
